properties.pname: Geochemistry of critical minerals in mine wastes in New Mexico
properties.affiliatio: New Mexico Bureau of Geology and Mineral Resources
properties.pdescrip: Mine wastes characterization in the Steeple Rock district, New Mexico
properties.pkeyword: water chemistry; arsenic; bismuth; cobalt; fluorine; magnesium; manganese; nickel; rare earth elements; tellurium; tungsten; zinc; abandoned mines and quarries; geologic maps; partnerships; mine waste; mineral deposits; study areas; critical minerals; geochemistry
properties.abstract: There are tens of thousands of inactive or abandoned mine features in 274 mining districts in New Mexico (NM), including coal, uranium, metals, and industrial minerals districts. Many of these mines have related mine waste materials, which could have potential for containing critical minerals, because the actual mineral production was generally for precious and base metals and not critical minerals. Therefore, any critical minerals that occur naturally in the mineral deposits would presumably be present in the mine wastes. The New Mexico Bureau of Geology and Mineral Resources is conducting a project to characterize and estimate the critical mineral endowment of mine wastes in three mining districts in NM: (1) Copper Flat at Hillsboro, (2) Black Hawk in Burro Mountains, and (3) Carlisle-Center mines in Steeple Rock district. The Copper Flat mine is an example of a porphyry copper deposit, among other related deposit types. Known critical minerals in the district include Te, As, Bi, Mg, Mn, and Zn. The Black Hawk district (also known as Bullard's Peak) is an example of the arsenide mineral system and contains five-element veins among other deposit types. Known critical minerals in the district include Co, Ni, As, REE, Bi, W, Te, fluorite, and Zn. The Carlisle-Center mines are examples of a low sulfidation, volcanic-epithermal system and contain Au-Ag veins among other deposit types. Known critical minerals in the district include As, Bi, Te, fluorite, and Zn. Detailed maps will be produced, showing the geology and extent of mine wastes in the project areas within the three mining districts sampled and characterized. Approximately 100 composite mine waste samples (from mine dumps, low grade stockpiles, tailings from all three sites) will be collected for geochemical analysis in order to calculate the total critical mineral potential in these wastes. Samples will be selected for additional mineralogical, microbial, and leaching studies based upon the chemical analyses. Approximately 15 water samples for pH, major cation and anion and trace elements will be obtained from all three sites to determine if there are any critical minerals potential in the mine waters. Potential critical minerals in the project area: As, Bi, Fluorite, Mg, Mn, REE, Te, W, and Zn.
properties.alias: Geochemistry of critical minerals in mine wastes in New Mexico

Branch of chemistry that deals with the elements and compounds in water.
Nonmetal element with symbol As and atomic number 33 <http://periodic.lanl.gov/33.shtml>
Metalloid element with symbol Bi and atomic number 83 <http://periodic.lanl.gov/83.shtml>
Metal element with symbol Co and atomic number 27 <http://periodic.lanl.gov/27.shtml>
Halogen element with symbol F and atomic number 9 <http://periodic.lanl.gov/9.shtml>
Alkaline earth element with symbol Mg and atomic number 12 <http://periodic.lanl.gov/12.shtml>
Metal element with symbol Mn and atomic number 25 <http://periodic.lanl.gov/25.shtml>
Metal element with symbol Ni and atomic number 28 <http://periodic.lanl.gov/28.shtml>
A group of elements including the lanthanoids, or lanthanides, of interest because they are used in modern technological industries.  Yttrium and scandium are often included in this group.
Nonmetal element with symbol Te and atomic number 52 <http://periodic.lanl.gov/52.shtml>
Metal element with symbol W and atomic number 74 <http://periodic.lanl.gov/74.shtml>
Metal element with symbol Zn and atomic number 30 <http://periodic.lanl.gov/30.shtml>
Mines and quarries that have been abandoned and may expose harmful chemicals to the environment.

Maps depicting geological characteristics of the earth's surface, including lithology, geologic structure, age, and the results of crustal processes. Used where the product includes a depiction of the map as a whole, not for data sets that could be used to create a map.
Formal collaborative relationships between USGS and other organizations

Earth materials removed during mining and concentrated in piles or beds, typically near the site of extraction.  Tailings are mine waste that has been processed to remove valuable components; unprocessed mine waste includes overburden removed to reach commodity materials such as ore or coal.
Deposits in which particular minerals are concentrated, typically noticed and studied if the minerals have economic value.
Geospatial data describing the areas from which samples were taken or observations were made, typically polygonal.  May be approximate, as in bounding coordinates, or precise.

A non-fuel mineral or mineral material essential to the economic and national security of the US, the supply chain of which is vulnerable to disruption, and that serves an essential function in the manufacturing of a product, the absence of which would have significant consequences for our economy or our national security.
Study of the distribution of chemical elements and natural compounds on the earth and in the atmosphere and the chemical processes that affect the earth.
Areas where masses of naturally occurring mineral material are found, e.g. metal ores or nonmetallic minerals. [Adapted from Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

data_link.title: Geochemical data generated by projects funded by the USGS Earth Mapping Resources Initiative
data_link.descript: Includes all geochemical data generated by each project partnership funded through Earth MRI and will be updated periodically as additional geochemical data from these projects becomes available.
